results.title: Seven o'clock news
results.brief_description: Shows an ABC radio announcer preparing the script of the 7 o’clock news for transmission over the ABC network. A recruiting film illustrating many aspects of the work of the the PMG Department, including the provision of communications systems for radi broadcasting and the training of Post Office personnel as telegraphists, postal clerks and technicians.

results.title: Seven more stations
results.creator_credit: Victor Sheridan, Patrick Henry and Academy Picture Corporation
results.brief_description: A record of the opening of the Eastern Extension of London Transport’s Central line from Wanstead to Newbury Park, showing the planning, organisation and labour that went into the extension.

results.title: Seven little Australians: Eps. 4-6
results.creator_credit: Ron Way, Charles Russell, Ethel Turner Productions and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: The story of the Woolcot family, living in Sydney in the 1890’s. An Englishman in the New South Wales Regiment, Captain Woolcot is constantly harassed and embarrassed by the antics of his seven mischievous children: Meg, Pip, Judy, Nell, Bunty, Baby and ‘The General’. Episode 4: All for the worst: Bunty is plagued by the lies he tells, Meg makes efforts to be ‘grown up’ and Judy makes a tortuous trip home. Episode 5: Secrets: Judy arrives home worn out and ill, but makes the other children promise not to let Esther or the Captain know for fear of being sent back to school. Episode 6: Tomorrow do thy worst: Judy is still ill and the children try to take care of her. However, the Captain’s suspicions are aroused and he discovers Judy’s hiding place.

results.title: Seven little Australians: Eps. 1-3
results.creator_credit: Ron Way, Charles Russell, Ethel Turner Productions and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: The story of the Woolcot family, living in Sydney in the 1890’s. An Englishman in the New South Wales Regiment, Captain Woolcot is constantly harassed and embarrassed by the antics of his seven mischievous children: Meg, Pip, Judy, Nell, Bunty, Baby and ‘The General’. Episode 1: Fowl for dinner: Captain Woolcot is embarrassed by his children’s behaviour when they interrupt a dinner he is giving for his new Commanding Officer. Episode 2: What are fathers for anyway?: Pip and Judy find themselves in trouble after leaving the General unattended in their father’s office at Victoria Barracks, while they attend a carnival. Episode 3: Consequences: Judy is sent to boarding school at Mt. Victoria, but is determined to return home.

results.title: Seven little Australians. Eps. 7-10
results.creator_credit: Ron Way, Charles Russell, Ethel Turner Productions and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: The story of the Woolcot family, living in Sydney in the 1890’s. An Englishman in the New South Wales Regiment, Captain Woolcot is constantly harassed and embarrassed by the antics of his seven mischievous children: Meg, Pip, Judy, Nell, Bunty, Baby and ‘The General’. Episode 7: Into the sun: The doctor decides that Judy must recuperate in a warmer climate, but she is unwilling to be parted from the others. An invitation for the family to visit Esther’s parents at their country property, Yarrahappini, is accepted as a solution. Episode 8: Yarrahappini: While the Captain spends a lonely time at Misrule, his family enjoy their country holiday. Meg begins to fall in love with the property manager, Dick Gillet, but is disillusioned when she discovers he is an alcoholic. Episode 9: The Picnic: On the last day of their holiday at Yarrahappini, Esther goes to a ball with her father, and the children go off with the drovers for a picnic, which comes to a sad end when Judy is hit by a falling branch. Episode 10: Going home: Meg cares for Judy while Pip runs for the doctor, but it is too late and Judy dies. The family say goodbye to Judy and return home to their lives at Misrule.

results.title: Seven Little Australians (1973)
results.brief_description: Captain Wolcott is a widower with seven children. He marries again and his new wife takes on all the trials of bringing up seven spirited children. They have many adventures, especially one daughter Helen, commonly known as Judy.

constellations_other.name: Page to screen
constellations_other.description: Australian scribes and screenwriters unite on the silver and small screens.

results.title: Seven Little Australians
results.brief_description: Seven children live with their tyrannical father, Captain McCallum, and step mother Esther. The children can never make their father happy.

results.title: Seven days under Mavis
results.creator_credit: Anna Johnson, Michael Agar and Pig Hell Productions
results.brief_description: Based on real events, this short film explores the fate of Frank, an elderly man with a bad back, who is pinned beneath the body of his wife, Mavis, after she suddenly dies and collapses on top of him. For seven days in the heat of summer, Frank lies helpless. His back twisted in the fall, he finds his physical agony and despair turning to hatred of Mavis. He begins to hallucinate; past and present merge. Stripped of his physical strength, Frank is forced to search inside himself for the emotional resources which will save him.

results.title: Seven Days in May
results.creator_credit: John Frankenheimer, Edward Lewis, Joel Productions and Seven Arts
results.brief_description: American president Jordan Lymans (Frederic March) has signed a peace treaty with the Russians which results in a violent public opinion campaign against him. The treaty also incurs the wrath of conservative military brass General Scott (Burt Lancaster in a part inspired by the far-right ramblings of one General Edwin Walker), who considers this move towards disarmament as an act of treason. When Colonel Casey (Kirk Douglas) discovers a cryptic message on Scott’s desk relating to a top secret military base in Texas whose existence is unknown even to the Presidents, he becomes convinced that Scott will use the forthcoming Full Alert exercise to overthrow the US government. Having won the President’s trust, Casey gathers a small circle of loyal friends around him to go and seek evidence against Scott before the Alert deadline. All their efforts seem thwarted by accidental death or false imprisonment, until Casey obtains from Scott’s former lover Eleanor (Ava Gardner) incriminating letters that could be used to force his resignation. At a time of supreme US confidence in the solidity of their institutions, Frankenheimer delivered with ‘The Manchurian Candidate’ and ‘Seven Days in May’, two solid conspiracy theory films that were ahead of their time. Not before the 70s and a few fatal blows dealt to American optimism (Kennedy’s assassination, the Bay of Pigs), would the genre be revisited and flourish. ‘Seven Days in May’ is also a rare film: a taunt political thriller, rated G, with barely a gun shot or a swear word and whose razor-sharp dialogues and memorable quotes are delivered by old sparring partners Douglas and Lancaster. Based on the novel by Fletcher Knebel and Charles W. Bailey II
